Mazzy is a fine build, this is only a different way to build with the same classes. This warrior uses stealth, dual-wields and has more rogue and CoT. The lack of ranged focus frees up many feats. Power attack is there to add damage, to cover that weakness with dex builds, especially against sneak immunes. The AB is high enough to use power attack. You can do the same with Mazzy.
If you study the build, you will recognize several of the principles we discussed when you built Mazzy.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Kalistez wrote:
Just noticed that you haven't taken Blind Fight.

Wouldn't that be a better option than Power Attack ?
Good catch!
The answer is yes, and no. Blind fight is definitely a tweak worth mentioning.
Blind fight makes you a better fighter vs invisible and concealed creatures, and when blinded for different reasons. So if that is a common scenario where you play, then take blind fight.
The reason why I picked PA was that I wanted an extra means to generate damage. This is a dex build with epic dodge. The 20 rogue levels give 10d6 SA. But vs sneak immunes you only have +2 from strength and +6 from WS and EWS added to the weapon base damage. Adding +5 damage brings the damage somewhat closer to  what you expect from a strength build, and with a base AB of +45, you can afford to use PA vs many creatures.
In a low/mid magic environment with few options to add weapon damage, PA will serve it's purpose. In a high magic setting, all the weapon enhancements will make PA superfluous.
I have also spent feats in this build to make discipline compete with what you get from strength builds.
I guess you can say that this is a dex build that in some ways emulates a strength build without sacrificing the benefits of the dex build.

Valerfor wrote:
Take Blind Fight in place of SF: Discipline and leave PA as it is. If you do that, you will still end-up with the equivalent discipline skill of a warrior with 34 Str which is quite good.
You can do that too. It is a good suggestion and the end result will be good.
ESF discipline comes at level 36, and before that the discipline dumps come at intervals. So if you go that route, discipline can become a bit low at some points during leveling. I suggest an item with a discipline bonus to compensate for that if you experience frequent KDs at some point.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
You only need Search, Disable Trap, and Open Lock in chapter 1, up to level 9. After that, you will have a Rogue in your party to handle those things. Also, move Rogue 3 to level 5 so you won't have so many levels of not-Rogue in a row, or you'll wind up at level 6 with the skills of a level 3 Rogue. If you take Iron Will instead of Power Attack at level 18, your Will save should be OK. If you don't plan to be stealthy, that's a lot of points you put somewhere else, like Spellcraft and Concentration, with some left over for Lore.
An optional idea would be to use daggers instead of kukris, so you wouldn't need Exotic Weapons proficiency. You could use the feat you save to get Luck of Heroes at level 1, Weapon Focus at level 3, and Expertise at level 4.
That should be enough to convert this to a Aielund build.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Since this will be used on WoG :
Use Maces or Handaxes or Short Swords instead of Kukris. Less crits, but one size "bigger" and 1d6 instead of 1d4.
This will not matter, not in the slightest, as most opponents at higher levels have massive amounts of DR - meaning your base damage for these weapons will be mostly meaningless (with the possible exception of crits).  Elemental damage will play a more important role here.

So in the case of Crits, the Handaxes will of course do more damage here, due to the x3 modifier vs the Kukris x2.  However, they are Crit on a 20 (meaning you will need to roll a natural 20 to crit) so that is not going to happen all that often.  Kukris, on the other hand, are 18~20 for a Crit, meaning it will happen more often than in the case of Handaxes.

Keen will increase the Crit range by 1 here for the Handaxes, but by TWO here for the Kukris
The keen item property increases the critical threat range of a weapon by a range equal to the item's base threat range. In the absence of other modifications to the threat range, this doubles the range.
Improved Critical just makes the Kukris even more perverse, and only helps the Handaxes marginally.

So what one has to ask here, is how important is critting to the character (build) going to be?

If it is a central part of the build, then by all means, go with Kukris.  If it is just a bonus, then Handaxes will be fine, and may be preferred.

As for Blind Fighting, it is a great feat to have on WoG, due to everyone and their uncle, aunt, cousins, and distant relatives all sneaking about - and alot of them make use of invis as well.  So Blind Fighting is certainly one of those critical feats on WoG.  Due to massive amounts of meta-knowledge that I posses here, I myself would forgoe this in the build, but that is just me (there are ways to compensate for the lack of Blind Fight here, especially for this build).

So if going Handaxes, then yes, certainly do take Blind Fighting if dropping Exotic Weapons.

Skill Focus Disc is not really necessary imo on WoG - there are better ways to deal with KD there.  However, one should not totally discard the idea due to Disarm (which does get used against one on WoG, but it is not as prevalent as KD is imo).

I am not a proponent of Saving Throws.  It is my firm belief that immunites are greater than Saving Throws are, especially on WoG where you will be spammed with abilities that require a saving throw.  This means that inevitably you will roll a 1 (and due to how the NWN Engine works, it will happen ALOT!!!!) and you will fail it, regardless of what you have done to pump up your saves.

So imo, LoH is a wasted feat here.

Cleave is more useful.

I would suggest taking Toughness (and getting the extra hitpoints) instead of reducing Con and getting more Int here.  Greater Ruin has been buffed on WoG, and it can do over 400 hps of damage (just one).  This is sort of the mark that one always aims for on WoG, so that one can at least survive a hit of a GR (and scramble to suck down that Heal or two before the next one hits!).

posts.author: Stagmeister

Another factor that might be worth considering about crits is that they don't apply to sneak attacks, so whether to focus in a weapon with a better crit rating will depend on how much you intend to use sneaks.

You also mention taking Listen rather than Spot, which is fine, but you'll have to space out when you take it, as CoT has Spot as a class skill, but not Listen.

I can personally attest to what a great build this is to play (I've done the OC/Mines of Twin Summit, SoU/HotU/ Sands of Fate, and Aielund with her, and enjoyed each and every one). I'm pleased to see it getting some more love!

Cheers

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: Note that pre epic fighter and CoT end on 5 and 7 levels, enabling the next bonus feat to be an epic one. If you drop CoT and only take fighter, you will get one more pre epic feat and one less epic feat.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I wouldn't touch CoT even with a ten-foot pole in this build. Mick has succeeded in creating a rogue that isn't terrible at saving throws, don't waste that. And he has excellent AB, very good AC & ED. There are very few things that you can touch in this build without upsetting its delicate balance.

Halfling can become Elf, kukris can become handaxes & take blind-fight instead, SF: discipline can become toughness & later, if you have no need for it, ESF: discipline can become crippling strike. You can change spot for listen, too & you should spare a few points in set traps likewise, giving you more options. And that's plenty to take on anything, with this build, really.

About these Greater Ruins, they are terrifying, yes, but not so much for this build. With WoG modification they do 75d6 max, an average of 262 hit points & they offer a saving throw too, which you should be able to pass most of the time with your 30(32) Fortitude save (more with equipment), reducing that to 131 hit points, on average. This build with 12 con & toughness has 400 hit points plus whatever equipment you are likely to have, you'll be fine. How could you not be? You're the Elven Champion!

The rogue deals an additional 2 points of ability score strength damage when he makes a successful sneak attack.
So immunity to Sneak Attacks will block this.

Immunity to Critical Hits will not iirc.
